item.description:
A Florida widow is demanding a Manhattan auction house return her husband‚Äôs $2 million stamp collection after nearly a decade ‚Äî and believes some of the precious postage might now be missing.

The prized collection was amassed by Stanley Marks, who first started trading stamps in 1937 when he was just 10.

The lawyer, who became a member of the New York Stock Exchange in the 1950s, turned a childhood hobby into a passion until his death in 2016 at age 89, when the collection was turned over to Robert A. Siegel Auction Galleries.

The collection was split into International and US stamps, with Siegel Auction Galleries selling the International portion in 2016 for $750,000, Marks‚Äô widow, Shelly Entner said in court papers filed by the Stanley A. Marks Revocable Trust.

The auction house has held the US portion of the collection ‚Äî valued at $2 million ‚Äî on consignment ever since.

Entner and her son William visited in April to inspect the collection.

‚ÄúAt the on-site visit, Ms. Entner came to believe that some of the stamps that had been in the U.S. Collection at the time of consignment in 2016 were no longer there,‚Äù according to court papers.

The family demanded the collection be returned but claimed the auction house refused, then demanded the widow reimburse the company $56,000 for insuring the collection and release it from liability for any claims, Entner contended.

‚ÄúMs. Entner refuses to be taken advantage of by Siegel Auction, which has no right to demand a ransom for the return of the stamps,‚Äù said Entner‚Äôs lawyer, Wendy Lindstrom.

The widow is seeking at least $2 million in damages.

Siegel Auction denied the allegations calling the lawsuit ‚Äúentirely baseless‚Äù and said the family ‚Äúreviewed the collection at great length‚Äù during their April visit, and confirmed ‚Äúthat all of the stamps are there.‚Äù

‚ÄúSiegel has repeatedly offered to return the collection to Ms. Entner,‚Äù attorney Daniel Weiner said.
item.author: Kathianne Boniello

item.description:
He did this with a heavy heart.

A smelly, morbidly-obese married Long Island lawyer allegedly tormented his much younger lover for years ‚Äî setting up secret cameras in her apartment, a tracker in her car, and a keystroke recorder on her computer.

Ronald David Ingber allegedly manipulated the Bergen County woman until she was isolated from her family and dependent on him, then blasted out sexual photos and videos of her to friends and family when she tried to leave, she said in a lawsuit.

Having sex with Ingber, 52, was not easy, according to the victim, identified in Brooklyn Federal Court papers only as Jane Doe.

‚ÄúAt more than 550 pounds, Ingber had difficulty cleaning himself, causing [the accuser] to develop painful boils following sexual activity,‚Äù the 37-year-old said in court papers. ‚ÄúThe duty was not an easy or enjoyable one . . . between the smells and rashes.‚Äù

She also accused the father of two of giving her herpes.

The pair met online in 2018, with Ingber claiming he was in the midst of divorcing his wife, Jane Doe said.

The attorney allegedly convinced her to leave her job and move into an apartment he rented for her in Nassau County.

‚ÄúIngber monitored, manipulated, and controlled every aspect of [her] life,‚Äù even bizarrely convincing her they were under criminal investigation in New Jersey ‚Äî and that he would protect her, according to the lawsuit.

‚ÄúIngber‚Äôs covert surveillance was extensive and inescapable,‚Äù she said in legal papers.

When she tried to move out or end the relationship, which dragged on for four years, Ingber would convince her that he was ‚Äúher only ally,‚Äù even though ‚Äúhe was actually the one responsible for her misery.‚Äù

He hacked her devices, she said. With access to her email, Ingber ‚Äúor someone acting on [his] behalf began interfering with . . . cell phones, enabling him to view outgoing and incoming phone calls, delete photographs, and access and delete other content.‚Äù

The woman claims Ingber continues to send her unhinged messages.

She ‚Äúis tired of hiding from Ingber and desperately seeks the ability to move through her life freely and without the constant fear that he is tracking her.‚Äù

The accuser is seeking $150,000 per illicit image sent out by Ingber, along with unspecified damages for invasion of privacy and intentional infliction of emotional distress.

A lawyer for Ingber vehemently denied the allegations.

‚ÄúMr. Ingber flatly denies each of these patently false claims and is confident that a full litigation of this matter will expose Ms. Doe, who strategically identified, targeted and aggressively pursued Mr. Ingber,‚Äù attorney Richard Portale said in a statement.¬†
item.author: Kathianne Boniello

item.description:
Her ex-boos are haunting Hoboken.

A house on Garden Street decked out in Taylor Swift-themed Halloween decorations ‚Äî with the pop star‚Äôs famous exes‚Äô names etched on tombstones ‚Äî went viral with 2.5 million views on TikTok.

However, the cheeky display, which features Swift‚Äôs web of former flames like Harry Styles, Joe Jonas, John Mayer, Jake Gyllenhaal, Matty Healy and Joe Alwyn, failed to include some ghosts of her dating past ‚Äî and fans can‚Äôt ‚ÄúShake it Off.‚Äù

‚ÄúJustice for Tom Hiddleston,‚Äù one said of the British actor, who dated Swift in the summer of 2016.

‚ÄúNo Calvin [Harris]? I guess we forgot he existed,‚Äù another quipped of the Scottish DJ,¬†who courted the songstress from March 2015 to June 2016.

‚ÄúThank you for not adding Taylor Lautner,‚Äù wrote another, referring to the ‚ÄúTwilight‚Äù actor, who dated her for a few months in 2009, prompting the nickname ‚ÄúTaylor Squared.‚Äù

‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt she date a Kennedy? We can add him,‚Äù someone else said, referring to her brief 2012 dalliance with Conor Kennedy, the son of Robert F. Kennedy Jr.¬†‚Äî which has¬†recently sparked renewed controversy¬†since she was 22 at the time, while he was only 17.¬†¬†

The man behind the spooky setup told The Post the reason for the snubs was simple.

‚ÄúThere were so many that we didn‚Äôt want to spend $1,000 on these custom gravestones,‚Äù said Tim Dwyer, who decorated for the New Jersey homeowners, who wish to remain anonymous.

A skeleton of Swift and her new fianc√© Travis Kelce ‚Äî in a Chiefs jersey and on bent bony knee ‚Äî are prominently placed at the top of the stoop.

There‚Äôs even a jail cell holding a skeleton of Scooter Braun ‚Äî the record exec and current Sydney Sweeney fling who famously feuded with Swift over ownership of her first six albums.

Dwyer said the couple that owns the home contacted him as soon as they moved onto the block in uptown Hoboken, famed for its Halloween displays.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre like, ‚ÄòYou have to think of something that‚Äôll go viral . . . and his wife is a Swiftie,‚Äù he said.

It did, and the buzzworthy decor was even featured on the Instagram page Hoboken Weekend, where commenters marveled at Swift‚Äôs virtual cemetery of old flames.

‚ÄúBro, T Swift has to have the all time body count,‚Äù one said. ‚ÄúLook at those names on her hit list.‚Äù
item.author: Angela Barbuti

item.description:
In a scene out of ‚ÄúThe French Connection,‚Äù a wild new NYPD video shows cops hot on the tail of two alleged car thieves in a stolen muscle car racing through streets ‚Äî and on sidewalks ‚Äî in the Bronx.

Cops received an alert of a stolen vehicle around 11 a.m. Sept. 17 when a 2025 bright blue Dodge Charger tripped a license plate reader at East 167th Street and Morris Avenue.

One of the department‚Äôs drone pilots located the Charger as it rocketed through the streets of Claremont Village and broadcast its position to cops on the ground.

About a half dozen police cars chased the Charger, which tried to evade them by driving ‚Äúoff road‚Äù ‚Äî on the sidewalk ‚Äî down East 167th Street, cops said.

The chase came to a screeching halt about a mile later when the driver slammed into the side of an SUV stuck at a red light at Walton Avenue.

‚ÄúGet out the car! Get out the car!‚Äù a cop chasing the alleged thieves yelled, body camera video shows.

Both men inside the heavily-tinted windows of the Charger jumped out of the hot car and sprinted away, prompting two speedy officers to give chase.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs over there!‚Äù a pedestrian yells at the sprinting cop, while pointing at one of the wanted men.

‚ÄúGet down! Get down!‚Äù the gun-wielding cop yells at another pedestrian wearing a yellow parka as he closes in on the thief and cuffs him.

Plainclothes cops caught the second man, threw him to the ground and cuffed his hands behind his back, body camera video shows.

But the Hollywood-style action didn‚Äôt stop there.

When cops rolled the man onto his back, they found he had a gun under his body, the video shows.

‚ÄúI got it! I got it! I got it!‚Äù the cops barked, as one of them confiscates the firearm.

Emmanuel Torres, 26, of Newark, NJ, was hit with gun possession and criminal possession of stolen property, police said.

Ricky Fernandez, 25, of Linden, NJ, was charged with auto theft, criminal possession of stolen property, drug possession, and reckless driving, cops said. He was allegedly holding crack cocaine, police said.

Fernandez pleaded not guilty and was released on his own recognizance. Torres pleaded not guilty and was released with non-monetary conditions, according to court documents.
item.author: Tina Moore

item.description:
The gay personal assistant allegedly tormented and driven to suicide by Democratic Sen. Ron Wyden‚Äôs family stole money, jewelry, clothes, books and a pricey Disney pass from his boss ‚Äî Wyden‚Äôs wife, Strand bookstore owner Nancy Bass Wyden.

Bass Wyden, 64, detailed $655,000 in alleged thefts by the former assistant, Branden O‚ÄôBrien, in a Manhattan Supreme Court lawsuit against O‚ÄôBrien‚Äôs husband, Thomas Maltezos.

O‚ÄôBrien splurged on $1,200 Christian Dior sneakers and other luxe labels from Saks; shelled out nearly $1,700 on the Disney Incredi-pass; and stole an emerald pendant which belonged to Bass Wyden‚Äôs mother, according to court papers.

He even pilfered 37 books from The Strand, including Charles Darwin‚Äôs ‚ÄúOn the Origin of Species,‚Äù Franz Kafka‚Äôs ‚ÄúMetamorphosis‚Äù and Arthur Conan Doyle‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Lost World,‚Äù all in hardcover from The Folio Society and worth nearly $9,000, she said in the legal filing.

O‚ÄôBrien and Maltezos sold the items on Poshmark, she contended.

The assistant even used Bass Wyden‚Äôs Amazon Points to send himself more than $42,000 in gift cards, she alleged.

O‚ÄôBrien, who quit in September 2024, was under investigation by the NYPD but the probe was dropped when he killed himself in May at age 35.

Maltezos has denied the theft allegations.And in his own legal filing accused Bass Wyden of allowing her young children to taunt O‚ÄôBrien with homophobic and sexually explicit remarks and ruining his rep so he couldn‚Äôt find another job.

Bass Wyden and her children spend most of their time in New York, while the Oregon senator ‚Äî a frequent critic of President Trump ‚Äî splits his time between the Beaver State, Washington DC and the Big Apple.

‚ÄúThe claims filed against me are not only baseless but calculated to divert attention from O‚ÄôBrien‚Äôs systematic theft and manipulation of both me and our impressionable children, who were only 14 and 9 years old when O‚ÄôBrien began working for me,‚Äù Bass Wyden said in a statement.

She accused Maltezos of playing ‚Äúa complicit role‚Äù in the thefts.

The lawsuit is ‚Äúa blatant act of retaliation against Thomas for refusing to withdraw his wrongful death and employment discrimination claims on behalf of his late husband, Brandon,‚Äù Maltezos‚Äô attorneys, Reyna Lubin and Eric Baum, said in a statement.

‚ÄúRather than taking responsibility for the documented homophobic slurs and the horrific treatment Brandon endured, as outlined in Thomas‚Äôs complaint, she has chosen instead to attack those seeking justice.‚Äù
item.author: Kathianne Boniello

item.description:
The Big Apple could be underwater as the work week begins, with an intense nor‚Äôeaster expected to sock the city this weekend with significant rain and strong winds.

Forecasters say the storm could dump between 1.5 to 3 inches of precipitation throughout the five boroughs beginning Sunday night and continuing into Monday ‚Äî but officials are warning the total amounts could be much higher.

‚ÄúThe combination of persistent, strong onshore winds, high surf and high astronomical tides may lead to some East Coast communities experiencing¬†significant coastal flooding impacts,‚Äù the National Weather Service warned.

New Yorkers living in low-lying zones and on the coast should prepare for flooding the likes of which filled basements and subways rapidly in July.

Communities along southern Brooklyn, southern Queens, the eastern shore of Staten Island, and the Bronx shoreline are at greatest risk for flooding and storm impact, the city‚Äôs Emergency Management warned.

The rainfall was forecasted to start as a trickle throughout the day Saturday before gearing up after 8 a.m. on Sunday.

By Sunday evening, rain could be a constant presence, while winds reach 23 mph with gusts as high as 41 mph, the NWS said.

That forecast will stay steady throughout the day Monday, only easing up into evening hours.

Coastal Flood Watches are in effect from Sunday through Monday as 12‚Äì15-foot waves could mean some areas could see tides reach 2‚Äì4 feet above normal ‚Äî meaning significant beach erosion and dune breaching is possible for coastal communities.

New Jersey was under a state of emergency starting as early as midday Saturday to prepare for the threat.

The NYCEM is encouraging the Big Apple‚Äôs coastal neighborhoods and other flood-prone areas to take action on Saturday to get ahead of the chaos, including making a Go-bag with vital supplies in case of an emergency evacuation.

New Yorkers were also encouraged to gather supplies ahead of time, relocate parked cars to higher ground and proactively clear out local sewage drains to facilitate rainfall drainage.

The flood conditions can be monitored in real-time using the NYCEM‚Äôs FloodNet website floodnet.nyc.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre keeping a close eye on this storm as it moves up the coast,‚Äù said‚ÄØNYCEM Commissioner Zach Iscol.‚ÄØ

‚ÄúWhile the exact impacts will depend on the storm‚Äôs track, we‚Äôre expecting strong winds and coastal flooding, especially in our shoreline communities. We encourage all New Yorkers to begin preparing now: make a plan, check on your neighbors, and sign up for Notify NYC alerts.‚Äù¬†
item.author: Katherine Donlevy

item.title: Êñ∞Ê≥ΩË•øÂ∑ûÂ≠¶Ê†°Ëë£‰∫ã‰ºöÊØîËµõË¢´ÂçëÈÑôÁöÑÊñáÂ≠óÂä®ÊëáÔºåÊîªÂáª‰øùÂÆàÁöÑÂ¶àÂ¶àÂíåÂ•πÁöÑË∫´‰ΩìÔºö ‚ÄúËøô‰∏™Â©äÂ≠êÈúÄË¶ÅÊ≠ª‚Äù
item.description:
A New Jersey school board candidate was caught red-handed sending vicious, sexual messages about a conservative female board member in a group chat labeled ‚ÄúThisBitchNeedsToDie.‚Äù

Photos of Scott Semaya‚Äôs vile texts about Danielle Bellomo at a July school board meeting leaked this week on social media ‚Äî and the widening scandal is now being investigated by local cops and roiling the affluent suburb of Marlboro.

‚ÄúBellomo must be cold ‚Äî her nips could cut glass right n‚Äù read one text, allegedly captured on camera while Semaya‚Äôs fingers typed an ‚Äúo.‚Äù

Outrage was immediate, and Semaya this week dropped out of the race for the Marlboro Board of Education, followed by his running mate Melissa Goldberg.

The scandal in the leafy Monmouth County enclave has drawn parallels to the recent controversy in Virginia, where attorney general candidate Jay Jones was recently outed for a 2022 text message suggesting the state‚Äôs then-Republican House Speaker deserved to be shot in the head.

‚ÄúIt was absolutely terrifying,‚Äù Bellomo exclusively told The Post. ‚ÄúWhen I found out about the messages I was absolutely shocked, especially with the climate of our country. It sent chills down my spine.

Bellomo, 38, is a MAGA-loving, President Trump-supporting mom of three and staunch Republican, who poses in a star-spangled bikini for her Facebook profile picture. She believes she has been targeted for her politics.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a proud and unapologetic advocate for parental rights, for my children, for our town and our state and for that they have this hate for me,‚Äù she said.

Semaya, 38, an accountant who has voiced progressive liberal views, was one of five candidates running for three open seats on the Marlboro Board of Education. He cited only ‚Äúfamily circumstances‚Äù in announcing his exit from the race. He did not return multiple messages seeking comment.

‚ÄúMy whole family has been affected by it,‚Äù Bellomo said, noting her older son, 12, was likely to see the nasty text.

Ironically, Bellomo was once Semaya‚Äôs daughter‚Äôs Girl Scouts leader.

‚ÄúThis is heartbreaking for me,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThis is what he was thinking when I was volunteering with his children ‚Äî it‚Äôs a hard pill to swallow.‚Äù

Bellomo, who is serving her first full, three-year term on the board, said she‚Äôs been subjected to months of online threats and made several police reports.

While the social media post about the ‚ÄúThisBitchNeedstoDie‚Äù group text included just a single shot of Semaya‚Äôs cell phone, Bellomo said she‚Äôs seen several other images of the messages exchanged by the group including ‚Äúvery specific actions that they want to do to me and what their intention is.

‚ÄúThese text messages¬†are the first time¬†I was able to see they don‚Äôt want me alive,‚Äù she added, declining to share the additional images.

Bellomo said she has a protective order against one person allegedly in the group chat: Mitesh Gandhi, whose wife is a board member. Gandhi declined comment and referred The Post to his lawyer, who said he was moving to dismiss the protective order.

The vicious chat group was believed to be composed of five men, and allegedly included Chad Hyett, current Marlboro school board vice president, according to a source. Many in the town of 41,000 are now calling for Hyett‚Äôs resignation.

Hyett, who in December filed a School Ethics Commission complaint against Bellomo after she posted part of a board email on social media, did not return a message. The commission did not substantiate Hyett‚Äôs complaint.

Bellomo claimed Marlboro Schools Superintendent Michael Ballone ‚Äúwould not provide protection‚Äù at a board meeting this week, after the text message controversy erupted.

‚ÄúThe district takes the safety and security of all members of our school community very seriously,‚Äù Ballone said. ‚ÄúWe have an invaluable relationship with our local police department who attends our Board of Education meetings. This upcoming meeting will be no different.‚Äù¬†

Marlboro‚Äôs Democratic mayor, Jonathan Hornik, condemned the messages as ‚Äúcompletely unacceptable,‚Äù adding, ‚Äúthose responsible are clearly not equipped to hold public office.‚Äù

‚ÄúViolence and threats of violence against public officials are seemingly becoming normalized,‚Äù he said in a statement. ‚ÄúIn only a few months‚Äô time, we have witnessed an alarming escalation in this type of behavior to an extreme, culminating in the murders of Minnesota Representative [Melissa] Hortman and activist Charlie Kirk. This must stop.‚Äù

Meanwhile, the sleepy town of Marlboro, where the average home is priced at $850,000, has become a social media battleground.

‚ÄúThis guy presents himself as a father and family man to the public only to then conduct himself like a pervert and criminal on a group chat during a BOE Meeting,‚Äù wrote former board member Aldo Patruno of Semaya.

‚ÄúThis is disgusting on every level,‚Äù another online commenter said.

‚ÄúThese grown men need to be arrested for threats on one‚Äôs life,‚Äù another wrote on Instagram.

Semaya and Goldberg were running on a purportedly apolitical slate called Collaborators for Responsible Education, or CORE. The third candidate on the slate, longtime incumbent Michael Lilonsky, remains in the race. He did not return a message.

Goldberg told New Jersey‚Äôs Patch.com she was abandoning her bid for the board because she ‚Äúcurrently cannot commit to this role in addition to my other responsibilities.‚Äù
item.author: Kathianne Boniello

item.title: Ôºà‰Ω†ÊÉ≥ËÆ©Â•πÊ¥ª‰∏ãÂéªÂêóÔºü ‚ÄúSIÈùíÂ∞ëÂπ¥Â´åÁñë‰∫∫Âú®Ê∂âÂ´åÊñ©È¶ñÂ¶àÂ¶àÁöÑÁî∑ÊúãÂèãÂêéÂêëÂßêÂßêÊèêÂá∫‰ª§‰∫∫‰∏çÂØíËÄåÊ†óÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢ò
item.description:
The Staten Island teen accused of beheading his mom‚Äôs boyfriend allegedly showed his little sister the mutilated body ‚Äî then asked if she wanted their mother to live.¬†

‚ÄúShe said, ‚ÄòAre you gonna hurt mom?‚Äô ‚Äù the suspect‚Äôs weeping mother, Alicia Zayas, said of her 16-year-old daughter Bri‚Äôs encounter with her blood-soaked son, Damien Hurstel, in the Monday horror.

‚ÄúAnd he said, ‚ÄòDo you want her to live?‚Äô

‚ÄúAnd she said, ‚ÄòYes, please.‚Äô

‚ÄúHe said, ‚ÄòOkay, she‚Äôll live.‚Äô ‚Äù

Bri then asked her brother if she could leave the blood-spattered bathroom where, sources said, the killer removed some of Anthony Casalaspro‚Äôs brain with a spoon. Casalaspro was the mother‚Äôs live-in boyfriend.

‚ÄúAre you gonna tell mom?‚Äù Damien then asked his sister.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she replied, according to a heartbroken Zayas, who spoke exclusively to The Post Friday in a 30-minute sitdown in the office of her attorneys‚Äô Mark Fonte and Louis Gelormino.

Bri fled, hid behind a backyard shed and immediately phoned her mother.

‚ÄúShe called me scared,‚Äù the 39-year-old Zayas recalled. ‚ÄúI could hear it in her voice. I said, ‚ÄòAre you somewhere safe?‚Äô

‚ÄúShe said, ‚ÄòDamien killed Anthony, and he doesn‚Äôt have a head.‚Äô ‚Äù

Cops said Damien, 19, confessed to stabbing Casalaspro, 45, and sawing off his head inside the family‚Äôs Cary Avenue home in West Brighton. He faces charges of second-degree murder, manslaughter and criminal possession of a weapon.¬†

A photo of the grisly scene shows the severed head lying next to the corpse, shirtless and clad in red briefs, inside a walk-in shower. On the floor nearby is a bowl and a saw. A plastic sauce ladle lies on the victim‚Äôs chest, while the handle of a silver-colored spoon sticks out of the dismembered skull.

A desperate, panicked Zayas raced home to find Bri. Before she rushed into the house, where the front door was wide open, she told her daughter, ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt hear from me in two minutes, you need to call 911. Tell them to come quickly.‚Äù¬†

The terrified mom walked upstairs with her keys in her hand and entered her family‚Äôs apartment.¬†

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs blood everywhere,‚Äù she recalled. Damien was in the kitchen, wearing a disturbing expression.

‚ÄúHis eyes looked different,‚Äù she recalled. ‚ÄúHe has light eyes. The eyes looked dark. It looked weird. I said ‚ÄòDamien, what‚Äôs going on? What‚Äôs wrong, honey? What are you doing?‚Äô ‚Äù

‚ÄúCleaning,‚Äù Damien told his mother flatly, ‚Äúas if he‚Äôs cleaning dishes, like it‚Äôs normal.‚Äù

She then asked where Casalaspro was and her son said he was in the bathroom.¬†But ‚Äúyou don‚Äôt want to go in there,‚Äô‚Äù he chillingly warned.

‚ÄúI said, ‚ÄòWell, Damien, I have to go in there. I have to see Anthony.‚Äô ‚Äù¬†

The frightened mom slowly moved toward the bathroom ‚Äî too scared to turn her back to her son.¬†

She peered at the unimaginable bloodshed and began to scream, ‚ÄúWhy? Why? Why? Why? He loves you. Why would you do this?‚Äô‚Äù¬†

She called 911.

‚ÄúCome quick,‚Äù she told the dispatcher. ‚ÄúMy son killed my boyfriend.

‚ÄúThey said, ‚ÄòCan he be saved? ‚Ä¶ How do you know he‚Äôs dead?‚Äô

‚ÄúI said, ‚ÄòHe has no head.‚Äô ‚Äù

Zayas then ran outside and waited for police, begging the arriving officers not to hurt her son.

The mother insists this tragedy was preventable if the medical system had worked for her several mentally ill son.

Doctors changed her son‚Äôs medications in January without notifying her, said Zayas, who claimed Damien went downhill after the switch.¬†

She only found out when a CVS pharmacist pointed out that Damien needed to be weaned slowly off his previous medication, the antipsychotic drug Depakote.

She was never told what new meds he was supposed to be taking. Her son‚Äôs psychiatrist would not discuss treatment because Damien was now a legal adult.

‚ÄúWhy wouldn‚Äôt they tell us?‚Äù said Zayas. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre doctors. I‚Äôm sure they knew.‚Äù

Zayas insisted Casalaspro was not abusive ‚Äî but said her son could be violent. He beat her last year, on her birthday, when she asked him to clean the kitchen, she said.¬†

Damien started having mental health issues when he was only 6 ‚Äî after his father went to prison, she said. He began hallucinating at age 13 ‚Äî after being sexually abused by another student at a school in Queens, said Zayas, who declined to give more details.¬†

He was diagnosed with PTSD and major depression, she said. He saw ‚Äúshadow figures, very disturbing images, almost like horror movies,‚Äù she said. He would draw them for her.

That is when he was first prescribed antipsychotics.

Damien tried to kill himself twice, and was hospitalized twice, but by 14 was stable and on medication, she said.¬†

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just devastated,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMy son wasn‚Äôt like this before. He was a good boy. Something is seriously wrong with him.‚Äù¬†

When he was in high school, she was able to keep track of his doctors and medications. But despite her best efforts, she said she was cut out of the equation once he graduated in January and went into an adult mental-health program.

She attended his first two appointments with a new psychiatrist, but then her son told her she couldn‚Äôt come anymore.¬†

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt even know what doctors he was going to,‚Äù the mom said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even know if he was going to all the appointments. Every morning I remind him to take his medications. He said he was taking it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe ask the public to with hold judgment,‚Äù said Gelormino. ‚ÄúDamien Hurstel is an extremely troubled young man with a long documented history of mental health issues. Our firm is aggressively trying pursue his psychiatric history so we can get a complete picture of the circumstances leading up this tragedy.‚Äù

She and Casalaspro, a city Sanitation worker, were in the process of buying a home not far from where they lived.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm heartbroken,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnthony was a great man. He was helping me raise my kids. He didn‚Äôt have to do that.‚Äù
item.author: Tina Moore

item.title: Luigi MangioneÁöÑÂæãÂ∏àÂØªÊ±ÇÈ©≥ÂõûÊöóÊùÄUnitedHealthcareÈ¶ñÂ∏≠ÊâßË°åÂÆòÁöÑËÅîÈÇ¶ÊåáÊéß
item.description:
Lawyers for Luigi Mangione asked a New York federal judge Saturday to dismiss some criminal charges, including the only count for which he could face the death penalty, from a federal indictment brought against him in the December assassination of¬†UnitedHealthcare‚Äôs chief executive.

In papers filed in Manhattan federal court, the lawyers said prosecutors should also be prevented from using at trial his statements to law enforcement officers and his backpack where a gun and ammunition were found.

They said Mangione was not read his rights before he was questioned by law enforcement officers, who arrested him after Brian Thompson was fatally shot as he arrived at a Manhattan hotel for an investor conference.

They added that officers did not obtain a warrant before searching Mangione‚Äôs backpack.

Mangione, 27, has pleaded not guilty to state and federal charges in the fatal shooting of Brian Thompson on Dec. 4 as he arrived at a Manhattan hotel for his company‚Äôs annual investor conference.

The killing set off a multi-state search after the suspected shooter slipped away from the scene and rode a bike to Central Park, before taking a taxi to a bus depot that offers service to several nearby states.

Five days later, a tip from a McDonald‚Äôs about 233 miles away in Altoona, Pennsylvania, led police to arrest Mangione.

He has been held without bail since then.

Last month,¬†lawyers for Mangione¬†asked that his federal charges be dismissed and the death penalty be taken off the table as a result of public comments by US Attorney General Pam Bondi.

In April, Bondi directed prosecutors in New York to seek the death penalty, calling the killing of Thompson a ‚Äúpremeditated, cold-blooded assassination that shocked America.‚Äù

Murder cases are usually tried in state courts, but prosecutors have also charged Mangione under a federal law on murders committed with firearms as part of other ‚Äúcrimes of violence.‚Äù

It‚Äôs the only charge for which Mangione could face the death penalty, since it‚Äôs not used in New York state.

The papers filed early Saturday morning argued that this charge should be dismissed because prosecutors have failed to identify the other offenses that would be required to convict him, saying that the alleged other crime ‚Äî stalking ‚Äî is not a crime of violence.

The assassination and its aftermath has captured the American imagination, setting off a cascade of resentment and¬†online vitriol¬†toward US health insurers while¬†rattling corporate executives¬†concerned about security.

After the killing, investigators found the words ‚Äúdelay,‚Äù ‚Äúdeny‚Äù and ‚Äúdepose,‚Äù written in permanent marker on ammunition at the scene.

The words mimic a phrase used by insurance industry critics.
item.author: Associated Press

item.title: Êñ∞Ê≥ΩË•øÂ∑ûÂÆ£Â∏ÉËøõÂÖ•Á¥ßÊÄ•Áä∂ÊÄÅÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Nor 'easterÈÄ†ÊàêÊ≤øÊµ∑Ê¥™Ê∞¥Â®ÅËÉÅ
item.description:
A budding and potentially powerful Nor‚Äôeaster is threatening to bring ‚Äúmajor‚Äù coastal flooding impacts to parts of the mid-Atlantic Sunday into Monday, prompting New Jersey to already declare a state of emergency.

The combination of strong and persistent northeast winds and high astronomical tides will send pounding surf into the Atlantic coast from Virginia to New England.

But the brunt of the flooding appears focused on the New Jersey and Delaware coasts, along with Delaware Bay.

Coastal Flood Watches are in effect from Sunday through Monday as 12‚Äì15-foot waves could mean some areas could see tides reach 2‚Äì4 feet above normal.

‚ÄúModerate to Major coastal flood impacts are increasingly likely,‚Äù National Weather Service forecasters in Mount Holly, New Jersey wrote Friday morning. ‚ÄúWidespread roadway flooding and impassable roads, inundation of structures, and evacuations are possible Sunday-Monday.‚Äù

Forecasters say significant beach erosion and dune breaching is also possible due to very high surf.

Acting New Jersey Governor Tahesha Way says all 21 counties in New Jersey are in a statewide emergency starting midday Saturday due to the storm‚Äôs threat.

The declaration will help speed up emergency services and free up more resources for storm preparations and response.

‚ÄúStarting on Sunday, a dangerous coastal storm will begin to move past our state with extreme weather conditions for several counties, especially those on the Shore,‚Äù Way said. ‚ÄúI urge all New Jerseyans to exercise caution, monitor local weather forecasts and warnings, stay informed on evacuation protocols, and remain off the roads unless absolutely necessary.‚Äù

High Wind Watches are also in place from Long Island through coastal New Jersey and Delaware.

Wind gusts could reach upwards of 60 mph with sustained winds around 25-35 mph along the coast, fueling the high surf.

Already, New York has suspended Fire Island ferry service for Sunday and Monday.

Even areas inland could see flash flooding from heavy rains.

A widespread swath of 3-5 inches of rain is possible along the coast through Tuesday.

NOAA‚Äôs Weather Prediction Center has issued a large Level 2/4 flash flood risk from Norfolk, Virginia, through Philadelphia, New York City, and southern New England for Sunday.
item.author: FOX Weather

item.title: ÈïøÂ≤õÈïáÂú®„ÄäÂçéÁõõÈ°øÈÇÆÊä•„ÄãÊõùÂÖâ‰ªñÁöÑ‰ªáÊÅ®Ë®ÄËÆ∫Âá†‰∏™Â∞èÊó∂ÂêéÔºåÊâç‰∏∫‚ÄúÂÅèÊâß‚ÄùÁöÑ‰∫§ÈÄö‰∏ìÂÆ∂Ëæ©Êä§
item.description:
The Long Island town that hired a traffic expert who later admitted in court that his personal views could be seen as bigoted has fired the consultant and backtracked on its previous defense of him.¬†

Jeffrey Buckholz was terminated by the Town of Oyster Bay just hours after The Post exposed his long-string of hateful and anti-Muslim LinkedIn posts, and his sworn admission that he could be considered a bigot under oath, according to town officials and court records.

Buckholz, was hired by town officials to study traffic around a local mosque in a long-standing lawsuit battle between Oyster Bay and the Muslims of Long Island group, which wants to expand a mosque in Bethpage.¬†

‚ÄúWe are shocked and outraged to learn of this, and are immediately dismissing him from this case,‚Äù Oyster Bay Supervisor Joseph Saladino said Thursday.¬†

During his Oct. 3 deposition in the federal suit filed by the Muslim group against the town, Buckholz admitted that his views on Muslims and immigrants could be considered bigoted, according to the official transcript.

He also doubled down on the racist social media posts that littered over on his professional LinkedIn, according to the court transcript.¬†

The posts included liking one that said ‚ÄúMuslims can f‚Äìk off,‚Äù commenting that ‚Äúthey want to conquer us‚Äù under a post about Mayor Eric Adams declaring Prophet Muhammad‚Äôs birthday a holiday, and joking ‚Äúgators gotta eat too‚Äù under a post about migrants in Alligator Alcatraz, according to court docs and screenshots of his social media obtained by The Post.

Under oath, Buckholz said he opposed ‚Äúimporting outside cultures into the United States,‚Äù which he called a ‚ÄúChristian nation,‚Äù described the Islamic call to prayer as ‚Äúatrocious,‚Äù and claimed New York City mayoral hopeful Zohran Mamdani poses ‚Äúa bigger threat to New York than the 9/11 hijackers,‚Äù according to his sworn deposition.

But Saladino‚Äôs statement of outrage sharply contrasts the town‚Äôs own comment from just a day earlier ‚Äî in which Town Attorney Frank Scalera fiercely defended Buckholz.

Before The Post‚Äôs report, Scalera blasted MOLI‚Äôs motion to have the so-called expert‚Äôs traffic analysis tossed and bar him from testifying on the basis that he is tainted with bias as a ‚Äúforeign-based law firm attempting to turn this local land-use case into a political spectacle.‚Äù¬†

Scalera also accused the group‚Äôs Linklaters attorneys of ‚Äúdirty tactics‚Äù and ‚Äúdragging President Trump‚Äôs name, immigration policies, and core American values‚Äù into the case, calling it a ‚Äúfrivolous‚Äù attempt to pressure the town into approving the mosque‚Äôs expansion.

Now, less than 24 hours later, those same officials are walking back their defense and distancing themselves from Buckholz, claiming they were unaware of his racist posts or deposition remarks until they were made public.

The town‚Äôs reversal adds yet another twist to the years-long federal discrimination case, which has already seen the Justice Department intervene on behalf of MOLI and Oyster Bay officials admit under oath to creating a fake grandma witness while changing zoning laws to target non-Christian houses of worship.

‚ÄúWe welcome the Town‚Äôs decision to withdraw Mr. Buckholz,‚Äù Linklaters attorney Muhammad Faridi told The Post.

‚ÄúHis open prejudice epitomized the bias that has tainted this process from the start. His involvement made clear that this case has never been about legitimate land-use concerns ‚Äî it has been about discrimination and poor judgment,‚Äù he added.
item.author: Brandon Cruz

item.title: Zohran MamdaniÂä†ÂÖ•Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Ê∞ë‰∏ªÂÖöÂèÇÂä†Â∑¶ÁøºÁà±ÊÉÖËäÇÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫‰ªñ‰ª¨ÊøÄÁÉàÂú∞‰∏∫Ë¢´Ëµ∑ËØâÁöÑAG Letitia JamesËæ©Êä§
item.description:
Mayoral front-runner Zohran Mamdani and his lefty comrades are standing by state Attorney General Letitia James amid her indictment woes.

The Queens socialist fiercely defended James against the Trump administration during a love-filled news conference in Manhattan Friday, arguing the mortgage fraud case against her is politically motivated vengeance.

‚ÄúThis is a blatant miscarriage of justice. This is a shameless act of political retribution,‚Äù Mamdani seethed about the federal charges of bank fraud and making a false statement to a financial institution unveiled Thursday against James.

‚ÄúAnd instead of prosecuting Tish James for doing her job, Donald Trump should be doing his.‚Äù

James won a civil judgment against the president and Trump Organization last year for inflating the value of his real estate empire, leading to $355 million in penalties that were ultimately thrown out after an appeal and Trump‚Äôs white-hot ire.

The Trump-hating, James-loving rally also served as the latest chapter in a budding political romance between Mamdani and the attorney general.

The pair have bonded as unsparing critics of Trump and targets of his wrath.

James had supported City Council Speaker Adrienne Adams in the Democratic mayoral primary, but went ‚Äúall in‚Äù on Mamdani after his stunning victory in June.

Behind-the-scenes, James spoke with Gov. Kathy Hochul several times before her shock endorsement of Mamdani last month, the New York Times first reported.

She also guided Mamdani through the aftermath of July‚Äôs mass shooting in Midtown, in which an NYPD officer was among those killed, The Times reported.

Adams, alongside a slew of other local lefty Dems, joined the James-supporting event organized by Mamdani ‚Äî and even took shots at the democratic socialist‚Äôs mayoral opponent, former Gov. Andrew Cuomo.

‚Äú(James) saw through you in the beginning and she saw through you in the end,‚Äù Adams said about Cuomo.

‚ÄúAnd at the end of both spectrums, Donald Trump is still pulling the strings in your vocal chords.‚Äù

Cuomo has no love for James, who launched 2021 sexual harassment investigation that ultimately led to his resignation as governor.

While other Dems blasted the indictment against James, Cuomo initially offered only a lukewarm statement on X that didn‚Äôt mention her by name.

Cuomo clarified his remarks in a follow-up statement to The Post on Friday.

‚ÄúThe weaponization and politicization of the justice system is wrong no matter which side you are on‚Äî period. It is wrong when Trump‚Äôs DOJ does it or when a Democrat does it, and it must be universally condemned,‚Äù Cuomo said.

‚ÄúI know firsthand as the White House weaponized the DOJ against me when I was governor of New York and three other democratic states during the height of COVID and it‚Äôs wrong that it appears to be happening with AG James and Former FBI Director Comey ‚Äî it is part of why people have lost faith in the Justice system, the cornerstone of our democracy,‚Äù he said.
item.author: Hannah Fierick, Matt Troutman

item.title: Âæ∑Â∞îÂ∑¥È°øÂ≠¶Ê†°ÂèóÂÆ≥ËÄÖÂú®ÂéÜÂè≤ÊÇ†‰πÖÁöÑÁ•ûËÅå‰∫∫ÂëòÊÄßËôêÂæÖÂÆ°Âà§‰∏≠Ëé∑Âæó500‰∏á$
item.description:
A former student who says he was sexually abused decades ago at the elite catholic Delbarton School in New Jersey was awarded $5 million by a jury this week.¬†

The verdict on Wednesday came after a five-week trial in Morris County Superior Court, where the anonymous victim, T.M., claimed a monk from the Benedictine Catholic middle and high school sexually abused him on New Years Eve in 1975.

Delbarton, located in tony Morristown, where tuition is $48,725 a year, said in a statement this week that they were ‚Äúextremely disappointed in the verdict in this trial.‚Äù¬†

In addition to expressing ‚Äúgenuine compassion for any victim of abuse,‚Äù Delbarton and church officials said that they ‚Äúdo not believe damages awarded in this case are either fair or reasonable.‚Äù

‚ÄúCrucially, the jury unanimously found that St. Mary‚Äôs Abbey and Delbarton School did not violate the New Jersey Child Sex Abuse Act,‚Äù the letter written by St. Mary‚Äôs Abbot Johnathan Licari and Delbarton headmaster, Father Michael Tidd, ‚Äúmeaning we did not know of the alleged abuse and there was no intentional misconduct.‚Äù

The jury will reconvene next week to determine punitive damages in T.M.‚Äôs suit.

It is the first Catholic clergy sex abuse lawsuit to go to trial following a 2019 New Jersey look-back law allowing decades-old child sex abuse cases to be filed, and the first of nearly 40 pending clergy sexual abuse lawsuits against Delbarton to reach a verdict.

Those sex abuse allegations include several clergy members at the school ‚Äî even a former headmaster.

Most recently, a 2021 lawsuit filed by a former student claims that he was raped and abused more than 150 times by a trio of monks as a Delbarton seventh grader in the 1970s.

‚ÄúI am very proud that the victim stood his ground and decided to tell his story,‚Äù Mark Crawford, New Jersey director for the Survivors Network of those Abused by Priests, told NorthJersey.com.¬†

‚ÄúThis should send a powerful message to all institutions that they must take allegations seriously,‚Äù Crawford said. ‚ÄúSurvivors should not be afraid to stand up and tell your truth, because justice will prevail.‚Äù

A new grand jury investigation is likely to additionally examine if a former top Delbarton clergy leader, Auxiliary Bishop Elias R. Lorenzo ‚Äî who could be the state‚Äôs next cardinal ‚Äî played a role in covering up accusations that rolled in while he helped helm the school, according to state leaders, advocates and an attorney representing dozens of Delbarton accusers.¬†

Delbarton boasts a long list of famous alumni, including ‚ÄúGame of Thrones‚Äù star Peter Dinklage, Yankees starting shortstop Anthony Volpe and former New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie‚Äôs sons.

Representatives for T.M. declined to comment.
item.author: Peter Senzamici

item.title: Ë¢´Ëµ∑ËØâÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶ËÇ°‰ªΩÂÖ¨Âè∏Letitia JamesÂ∞ÜÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÊîØ‰ªòÂ•πÁöÑÊ≥ïÂæãËæ©Êä§Ë¥πÁî®‚ÄîËøôÂèØËÉΩËä±Ë¥πÈ´òËææ1000‰∏áÁæéÂÖÉÔºö‰∏ìÂÆ∂
item.description:
ALBANY ‚Äì¬†New York Attorney General Letitia James could soak taxpayers for millions of dollars in legal bills as she fights her new federal indictment ‚Äî but she says she won‚Äôt be tapping into the $10 million state legal defense slush fund set up for that purpose.

Instead, she‚Äôs turning to the national Democratic Attorneys General Association to cover her legal defense bills against the bombshell mortgage fraud charges filed against her Thursday ‚Äì which could run in the millions, according to experts.

‚ÄúI think all in, it‚Äôs probably going to be in the range of $5 to $10 million,‚Äù former prosecutor Neama Rahmani told The Post Friday.

James has brought on high-profile defense attorney Abbe Lowell, who could be billing over $1,000 an hour and taking a $1 million retainer fee based on the going rate for top lawyers, Rahmani said.

But legal eagles also said that some lawyers may even take up the case pro-bono given its high-profile nature and some left-leaning attorneys‚Äô political convictions to stand up for James, a Democrat.

‚ÄúI think a lot of amazing attorneys would be happy to step up and do this for free,‚Äù former prosecutor Duncan Levin said.

A spokesperson for James‚Äô office told The Post Friday that she would not be tapping into the state fund to pay for her defense, after initially saying she would use it.

The state comptroller‚Äôs office confirmed that none of the $10 million in the stash has been drawn.

The provision to set up the fund ‚Äì¬†first revealed by The Post ‚Äì was quietly tucked into the state budget by Albany lawmakers and Gov. Kathy Hochul earlier this year.

GOP lawmakers railed against the measure before it was rammed through by the Democratic-controlled legislature.

James has denied the charges against her and claimed President Trump is targeting her for political reasons.

She‚Äôs expected to make her first appearance in federal court in Virginia on Oct. 24.

The AG is running for re-election next year and signaled her endorsement for Hochul‚Äôs own bid over the summer ‚Äî quashing the suggestion she‚Äôd mount a primary campaign against the incumbent as she did briefly ahead of the 2022 gubernatorial race.

James, who was first elected in 2018, makes $220,000 a year as attorney general.

On her 2024 financial disclosure provided to New York‚Äôs ethics panel, she reported also making between $5,000-$20,000 from her adjunct professor gig at Columbia University and $20,000 to $50,000 on her rental property in Brooklyn.

DAGA, a well-funded Dem AG‚Äôs group, announced the creation of its legal defense fund late last month that James and other officials could dip into.

It remains unclear as to who is funding the effort and how much it has in the bank for James at this point.

The website for people to donate to the DAGA legal defense fund seems to imply that it will not be a separate entity from the organization.

‚ÄúContributions will be used at DAGA‚Äôs sole discretion to support its programs and activities. DAGA may use all or part of a contributor‚Äôs funds, and disclose them as necessary, in states of its choosing,‚Äù a blurb on the donation page reads.

‚ÄúContributions to DAGA Legal Defense Fund will be used at the sole discretion of DAGA to support programs and activities related to legal efforts that promote democracy.‚Äù

If the fund is effectively handled in-house, it means DAGA could lump the legal defense donors in with the hundreds of thousands of dollars of contributions it already gets from hundreds of businesses and other individuals on public filings.

DAGA didn‚Äôt respond to questions from The Post.
item.author: Vaughn Golden, Priscilla DeGregory

item.title: Ê≥ïÂÆòÂØπÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Âú∞ÈìÅÊÆ¥ÊâìÁñØÂ≠êË°å‰∏∫ÁöÑ‚Äú‰∏•ÈáçÁ®ãÂ∫¶‚ÄùÁöÑ‰ª§‰∫∫‰∏çÂØíËÄåÊ†óÁöÑÈ¢ÑÊÑü‚ÄìÂú®Ëá¥ÂëΩË¢≠ÂáªÂèëÁîüÂâçÂá†‰∏™Êúà
item.description:
A judge chillingly foresaw David Mazariegos‚Äô escalating violence as he begrudgingly lowered his bail in an assault case ‚Äî just months before the maniac allegedly beat a beloved security guard to death outside a Brooklyn subway station.

The premonition by Manhattan Judge Robert Rosenthal was revealed in a transcript from a July hearing, after prosecutors couldn‚Äôt secure a felony assault charge against Mazariegos, 25, in a case with eerie echoes to his later alleged fatal beating of Nicola Tanzi, 64, this week.

‚ÄúThe severity of these is increasing over time,‚Äù Rosenthal said during the hearing, referring to Mazariegos‚Äô mile-long rap sheet, which mostly consisted of petty offenses until the assault in late June.

Mazariegos‚Äô charge in that case had been reduced to a misdemeanor, but prosecutors still pushed for the same $2,500 bail set when he‚Äôd been first arraigned on the felony, the transcript shows.

His court-appointed attorney, Gretchen Reeser, argued Mazariegos wasn‚Äôt a flight risk and should be released without bail based on his lack of violent history at the time ‚Äî a request that gave Rosenthal considerable pause, according to the transcript.

‚ÄúI mean that is the point but what mitigates against that is that this is the first violent crime,‚Äù the judge said, adding that the fact that the charges against Mazariegos increasingly becoming more serious ‚Äúis suggesting to me something other than returning to court.‚Äù

But Rosenthal, his hands effectively tied due to the misdemeanor charge, dropped Mazariegos‚Äô bail to $1,000 ‚Äî setting the stage for his release, during which he allegedly ramped up his violence Tuesday by beating Tanzi to death outside Jay Street-MetroTech station.

The failure to keep Mazariegos behind bars was seized by Diana Florence, who is running as an independent to replace Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg.

Florence contended Bragg‚Äôs policies and the state‚Äôs bail reforms led to Mazariegos‚Äô release.

‚ÄúTuesday‚Äôs tragedy was preventable,‚Äù she said in a statement. ‚ÄúNicola Tanzi didn‚Äôt have to die.‚Äù

Richard Fife, a spokesman for Bragg‚Äôs re-election campaign, shot back that Florence was ‚Äúshamelessly distorting the truth and exploiting a tragedy to score cheap political points.‚Äù

The court record shows that prosecutors mounted an aggressive case against Mazariegos after he allegedly sucker punched a security guard outside a Chelsea theater on June 24.

The alleged assault was a dire escalation from Mazariegos‚Äô lengthy criminal record at that point, which mostly consisted of petty offenses ranging from fare evasion to graffiti to larceny.

Prosecutors sought a felony assault charge and pushed for $5,000 bail during Mazariegos‚Äô arraignment July 2, records show.

Reeser argued during the hearing that Mazariego should get supervised release, telling the court he was a struggling artist who couldn‚Äôt afford bail. She noted he was working with the Youth Justice Network, a group that matches young people in the New York City‚Äôs justice system with advocates to help turn their lives around.

‚ÄúEven if he were convicted of the top count, a jail sentence is very unlikely, and monetary bail would amount to jail time for my client,‚Äù she said, according to a court transcript.

Judge Julieta Lozano disagreed, noting Mazariegos at the time had three open cases and a past misdemeanor arson conviction, and set bail at $2,500 cash.

But by July 8, prosecutors reduced the charge to a misdemeanor because the 65-year-old victim‚Äôs injuries weren‚Äôt enough to secure a felony indictment, officials said.

They still pushed for $2,500 bail and added additional misdemeanor assault charges against Mazariegos ‚Äî but Reeser again argued her client was turning his life around.

Mazariegos had completed an animation project internship in May and moved onto another eight-week arts internship through the Youth Justice Network, his lawyer said.

He also volunteered with several community organizations through the network, as well as helped with a literacy program called ‚ÄúRead It and Leave It,‚Äù Reeser said.

The troubled Mazariegos was living with his aunt in the Bronx, she said.

But Rosenthal didn‚Äôt completely buy that Mazariegos was headed onto the straight-and-narrow.

‚ÄúGiven the pattern of the increasing cases ‚Äî the increasing behavior, given the number of cases so quickly, which does absolutely ‚Äî is in opposition to everything that you are telling me,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúEverything I am hearing about him is he is a great guy, and he is progressing, and doing all of these things.‚Äù

Reeser acknowledged Mazariegos had ‚Äúissues,‚Äù but said he‚Äôs getting help ‚Äî prompting another skeptical reply by Rosenthal, according to the transcript.

‚ÄúBut it seems ‚Äî it is ‚Äî contrary to that, it seems like this behavior is new behavior that I
have not seen ‚Äî that you don‚Äôt see prior in the rap sheet and undermines my confidence in his appearance in court,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúLike something is going on here beyond this. And I want him here.‚Äù

Rosenthal set Mazariegos‚Äô bail at $1,000 to ensure he wouldn‚Äôt skip his next court hearing.

‚Äú(The) escalating nature of this case from the other cases leads me to determine that you pose a flight risk to avoid prosecution,‚Äù the judge said.

Mazariegos‚Äô bail was posted a few days later.¬†

He was busted again a month later after he allegedly jumped on top of a car in the Bronx, shattering its windshield, while maniacally yelling, ‚ÄúCome get me. Y‚Äôall afraid of the government,‚Äù court records state.

Mazariegos was released on his own recognizance in the case, which was his last arrest before Tanzi‚Äôs beating death in Brooklyn, for which he now faces a murder charge, records show.

His attorney couldn‚Äôt be reached for comment.
item.author: Kyle Schnitzer, Joe Marino, Matt Troutman

item.title: Âú®ËÅîÈÇ¶Ëµ∑ËØâÂêéÔºå AOCÊÅ≥ËØ∑ÊîØÊåÅËÄÖ‚ÄúÂåÜÂøô‚ÄùÂêëÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶ËÇ°‰ªΩÂÖ¨Âè∏Letitia JamesÊçêÊ¨æ
item.description:
Firebrand New York Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez quickly urged her supporters to throw some bucks to State Attorney General Letitia James Thursday to ‚Äúfight back‚Äù against her federal indictment.

The lefty congresswoman sent out an email asking for donations for James, claiming the Democrat was being unfairly attacked by President Trump after she was charged with mortgage fraud.

‚ÄúLetitia isn‚Äôt backing down, and we need to support her in this critical moment. Her campaign set a goal to receive 20,000 contributions before midnight to fight back,‚Äù AOC‚Äôs email read.

‚ÄúIf you can, will you rush a donation to Letitia James right now?‚Äù the pitch said. ‚ÄúYour donation will send a powerful message that you‚Äôre standing in solidarity with Letitia as Trump manipulates the Department of Justice.‚Äù

The email linked to an ‚ÄúActBlue‚Äù fundraising page, but it wasn‚Äôt immediately clear where the money was going to, whether to James‚Äô campaign or a legal defense fund.

Ocasio-Cortez labeled the link to the fundraising page the ‚ÄúLetitia James Legal Fund‚Äù in an Instagram story she separately put up asking for help for the embattled AG.

‚ÄúThe charges are completely baseless,‚Äù she said in the fundraising email. ‚ÄúThis is a dangerous escalation of Trump going after those who hold him accountable.‚Äù

A legal defense fund for James was started by the national group Democratic Attorneys General Association (DAGA) late last month.

The state‚Äôs chief law enforcement officer was hit Thursday with a federal indictment in Virginia charging her with bank fraud and lying to a financial institute.

James, who is set to make her first court appearance in the case October 24, has denied the charges, claiming Trump is playing politics and targeting her ‚Äî a sentiment echoed by Dem allies.

The president and James have long been bitter rivals dating back to his first term office.¬†

Her office successfully sued him for inflating the value of the Trump Organization, though the massive fine he was initially hit with was tossed on appeal in August.

Legal experts told The Post there is no explicit ban on politicians in New York transferring campaign cash to legal defense funds. But a James spokesperson said the AG, who is running for re-election next year, will be using the DAGA legal fund to cover her defense.

An email to Ocasio-Cortez‚Äôs campaign was not immediately returned.

‚ÄúWe stand with her, New Yorkers love this woman, I love this woman,‚Äù Ocasio-Cortez said on social media about James.

‚Äî Additional reporting by Vaughn Golden
item.author: Josh Christenson, David Propper

item.description:
FIRST ON FOX:¬†Rutgers University¬†is defending a professor who signed an online petition that seeks to disband the school‚Äôs Turning Point USA chapter from campus.¬†

The Change.org petition launched earlier this week accuses the¬†conservative group¬†of ‚Äúpromoting hate speech and inciting violence against our community.‚Äù

While Change.org does not allow the public to view the list of signatories, each petition features a rotating ‚ÄúRecent signers‚Äù carousel near the top of the page.¬†

While monitoring the ‚ÄúRecent signers‚Äù carousel, Fox News Digital noticed that Tia Kolbaba, an associate professor of religion at Rutgers, signed the petition to boot the right-leaning group.

‚ÄúRutgers University is committed to providing a secure environment ‚Äî to learn, teach, work and research, where all members of our community can share their opinions without fear of intimidation or harassment,‚Äù a spokeswoman for the school told Fox News Digital in a statement. ‚ÄúRutgers is committed to upholding the rights of students and faculty to free speech and academic freedom as fundamental to our community.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe university does not comment on specific personnel or student conduct matters,‚Äù the statement finished.¬†

Kolbaba did not return a request for comment.¬†

The petition began circulating less than a month after Turning Point‚Äôs founder,¬†Charlie Kirk, was assassinated during a campus event at Utah Valley University. Kirk‚Äôs alleged killer is Tyler Robinson, who is said to have written ‚Äúhey fascist, catch!‚Äù and left-wing slogans on shell casings.¬†

A TPUSA member at the school slammed the petition on Wednesday.

‚ÄúThe petition to disband our Turning Point chapter is blatantly defamatory,‚Äù Ava Kwan, outreach coordinator for the Turning Point USA chapter at Rutgers, told Fox News Digital in a statement.

‚ÄúThe accusations of ‚Äòinciting violence‚Äô and ‚Äòmaking threats‚Äô are complete lies,‚Äù Kwan said. ‚ÄúThe same people claiming we‚Äôre suppressing their free speech are actively trying to silence us for speaking the truth. It‚Äôs not just ironic, it‚Äôs hypocritical and absurd.‚Äù

The Turning Point chapter last week launched its own petition demanding Rutgers fire professor Mark Bray, whom they call ‚ÄúDr. Antifa.‚Äù Bray is the author of ‚ÄúAntifa: The Anti-Fascist Handbook,‚Äù a book that openly calls for ‚Äúmilitant anti-fascism.‚Äù

He has also been accused of being an Antifa financier, and noted in his book that, ‚Äúat the very least 50 percent of author proceeds will go to the International Anti-Fascist Defense Fund which is administered by more than three hundred antifa from eighteen countries.‚Äù

Amid the Trump administration‚Äôs crackdown on Antifa, Bray announced this week that he and his wife are¬†fleeing to Spain.¬†

Bray said his address was doxxed, and his life was threatened, prompting the move.¬†

The petition to remove TPUSA at Rutgers suggests the chapter was responsible for Bray ‚Äúfearing for the safety of their family due to threats and harassment cultivated by this group.‚Äù

There is no evidence to support that claim, and Kwan dismissed it.

‚ÄúAny opinion that challenges their worldview is immediately branded as ‚Äòhate speech,‚Äô a meaningless term weaponized to control dissent and protect their false narrative,‚Äù Kwan said. ‚ÄúThe petition, Bray‚Äôs retreat abroad, and my own doxxing by unhinged Rutgers leftists all tell the same story: they know they‚Äôre losing.‚Äù
item.author: Fox News

item.description:
New York Attorney General Letitia James‚Äô defense attorney against mortgage fraud allegations is high-profile DC lawyer Abbe Lowell ‚Äî known for repping other prominent Democrats including Hunter Biden.

James was hit with a bombshell federal indictment in Virginia Thursday, accusing her of lying on forms when she took out a loan for a home in the Old Dominion State, netting her $19,000 in savings.

Lowell, a go-to attorney for leading Dems in legal trouble, issued a statement defending the Empire State‚Äôs top lawyer against the accusations, saying she ‚Äúflatly and forcefully denies these charges.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe are deeply concerned that this case is driven by President Trump‚Äôs desire for revenge,‚Äù he said Thursday, referring to James‚Äô civil fraud case against Trump.

The high-profile lawyer ‚Äî whom James hired in April when the Trump administration launched its probe into her real estate dealings ‚Äî is also repping embattled Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook as she appeals her firing by the Trump administration, which claimed she also allegedly committed mortgage fraud.

Lowell is likely most well-known for his defense of Biden, the former first son, in his fun and tax case.

While Biden was convicted at a first trial of illegally owning a gun while hooked on drugs ‚Äî and pleaded guilty in a second case to committing tax evasion ‚Äî former President Joe Biden pardoned his wayward son before leaving office in December 2024.

And Lowell recently defended former New Jersey Sen. Bob Menendez, another prominent Democrat ‚Äî currently in prison serving an 11-year sentence while he appeals his federal conviction.

Menendez was found guilty at trial in July 2024 of taking bribes, including gold bars, in exchange for using the power of his office to serve the interests of wealthy businessmen and the countries of Qatar and Egypt.

But Lowell‚Äôs recent losing track record isn‚Äôt a reflection on the quality of his work, rather that he is willing to take on difficult cases that aren‚Äôt likely to succeed, former prosecutor Neama Rahmani told The Post.

‚ÄúThose cases were losers no matter who was defending them,‚Äù Rahmani said Friday.

As a criminal defense lawyer, especially defending federal cases, ‚Äúyou‚Äôre expected to lose,‚Äù Rahmani said. ‚ÄúAcquittals are the exception rather than the rule.‚Äù

James‚Äô case is also likely to be difficult to win because her statement claiming on documents that her Virginia home would be her primary residence ‚Äúseemed false on its face,‚Äù Rahmani said.

‚ÄúI think this is a very tough case to defend,‚Äù the lawyer said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not saying it should have been brought or prosecuted or that this is a good use of government resources,‚Äù Rahmani added, ‚Äúbut if you‚Äôre just defending the case straight up on the merits, it‚Äôs a false statement, it‚Äôs bank fraud.‚Äù

James was hit with one count of bank fraud and one count of making false statements to a financial institution for which she faces up to 60 years in prison and a fine of up to $2 million if convicted.

Prosecutors claim she bought a three-bedroom, one-bathroom Norfolk, Va. home in August 2020 for roughly $137,000 and took a $109,600 loan for it, which barred her from renting it out.

On loan documents and related forms, she said it would be a secondary residence, but on tax forms she designated the home as a rental investment property that she made thousands of dollars on, prosecutors alleged.

James is the second of Trump‚Äôs political enemies to be indicted in the span of a few weeks.

Former FBI Director James Comey was indicted last month for allegedly lying to Congress about his probe into the Trump campaign‚Äôs ties to Russia.

Both James and Comey have said they were targeted by the Department of Justice at the president‚Äôs bidding in retaliation for their investigations into him.

James won a $355 lawsuit against Trump when a New York judge found he inflated the value of his real estate empire to improve loan terms for years.

But Trump successfully appealed to have the massive judgment dismissed.

On Thursday, James, a Democrat, said the indictment against her was ‚Äúnothing more than a continuation of the president‚Äôs desperate weaponization of our justice system.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe is forcing federal law enforcement agencies to do his bidding, all because I did my job as the New York State Attorney General,‚Äù she said.

Comey, who pleaded not guilty in court this week, said after he was indicted that his ‚Äúheart is broken for the Department of Justice.‚Äù

Comey‚Äôs lawyer is his longtime friend Patrick Fitzgerald, a former Chicago US attorney.

Fitzgerald said he plans to seek to have the indictment dismissed on the grounds of vindictive prosecution and for the alleged wrongful appointment of US Attorney Lindsey Halligan ‚Äî who mounted the cases against James and Comey.

Halligan is Trump‚Äôs former personal lawyer. She was appointed to be the US attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia last month after her predecessor, Erik Siebert, was ousted by Trump.

James is scheduled for her first court appearance in the case on Oct. 24.

Lowell didn‚Äôt return a request for comment Friday.
item.author: Priscilla DeGregory

item.description:
He‚Äôs a real Monstera.

A cheating man and his plant clippings were tossed to an Upper West Side curb this week after his partner uncovered his illicit affairs ‚Äî and then left a scathing note on the ground that soon went viral.

The abandoned greens were dumped along West 83rd Street off Broadway, along with the hand-written missive airing out the former beau‚Äôs dirty laundry.

‚ÄúPlease take these cuttings. They are the last of the plants my cheating husband was growing. The apartment is mine now and these are not,‚Äù the handwritten note stated, with the final three words furiously underlined for emphasis.

‚ÄúFelt bad throwing them out because I would never do that to someone ‚Ä¶ I mean the plants.‚Äù

A snapshot of the note and the beautifully cultivated plants was shared by The West Side Rag Monday ‚Äî and quickly garnered more than 37,000 views.

The innocent greens were quickly snatched up by a sympathetic neighbor, though it‚Äôs not clear that the same could be said for their treasonous caretaker.

The alleged cheater promised to share his side of the story with The Post this week, but wilted ahead of a planned interview for fear of legal repercussions.

The pair is headed toward divorce, he shared.

His former better-half could not be reached for comment.

Neighbors were apparently more compassionate toward the abandoned plants, with several commenting on their concerns under the popular post.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs always the plants that suffer,‚Äù one user wrote.

‚Äúi love plants that come with lore,‚Äù said another.

One person indicated that the lost lover might be trapped in the leaves, writing: ‚Äúwould never bring such cursed items into my harmonious home.‚Äù

It wasn‚Äôt clear, but the plants appeared to be monstera and elephant ear‚Äôs ‚Äî both of which fetch a pretty penny for just a small clipping.

Both types are members of the Araceae family and are known to be toxic, but only when ingested by furry friends.

The scorned lover apparently kept dibs on the pottery, as the plants were plopped outside in plastic bags.
item.author: Katherine Donlevy

item.description:
They are riding to corral the epidemic of veteran suicides.

More than a dozen former military members are saddling up for a 20-mile trip on horseback though the streets of Manhattan Saturday as part of an effort to raise awareness of the tragic issue.

The seventh-annual Trail to Zero ride ‚Äì organized by equine therapy nonprofit BraveHearts ‚Äì will see veterans and their steeds trot from Ground Zero to Times Square and Central Park before returning south again to One World Trade Center.

For some former service members, like Brandon Spandet, the iconic ride brings attention to the fact that roughly 20 veterans die to suicide each day and shows the public the success of equine-assisted therapy.

‚ÄúI was very close to becoming one of the 20. It was a last ditch for me, I tried everything else,‚Äù 33-year-old Spandet, of Illinois, told The Post ahead of the grueling eight-hour ride. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know what else to do. I showed up for my first lesson and I‚Äôm lucky enough that I‚Äôm riding ‚Ä¶ [draft stallion] Beau.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs this monster, but he‚Äôs also this gentle giant,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúHe definitely saved my life.‚Äù

Spandet, also a first responder, recalled having difficulty transitioning back into civilian life after leaving the U.S. Army when he was referred to BraveHearts by the Department of Veterans‚Äô Affairs in 2022.

‚Äú[Beau] is the best listener: He‚Äôs seen me through bad 911 calls ‚Ä¶ and dealing with things from the military, and he doesn‚Äôt care,‚Äù Spandet said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs going to sit there, listen and ride it out.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a total mirror of me a lot of days,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúThe instructors know when you‚Äôre off, and it‚Äôs because the horse is off.‚Äù

BraveHearts President and CEO Meggan Hill-McQueeney said ‚ÄúHorses have a way of reaching people in moments when words fall short.‚Äù

‚ÄúTrail to Zero brings Veterans and community together, sparking important conversations about mental health, and reminding the public that we all play a role in supporting those in need,‚Äù she added.

‚ÄúHorses are an answer for so many veterans.‚Äù

According to the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, an average of 17 veterans die by suicide each day out of the roughly 130 suicides that happen in the total population. The number that has dropped from the 20 per day that occurred when BraveHearts launched Trail to Zero in 2017.

Spandet called the camaraderie of the ride life-changing.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what you do for your fellow man, and just helping out,‚Äù he said.¬†‚ÄúBy the end of [the ride] you‚Äôre hurt and you‚Äôre sore ‚Äì but you get to feel.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe fact that I‚Äôm given the opportunity to pay it forward ‚Äî if I can reach just one and we can save just one person ‚Äî then that‚Äôs worth all of it,‚Äù said fellow rider Amanda Bethards, a U.S. Navy veteran and certified therapeutic riding instructor at the nonprofit who joined in 2017 to manage her stress and anxiety.

Bethards, 40, has since participated in roughly a dozen rides including two in New York City. Similar rides have spurred in other cities since, including Chicago, Houston, Washington D.C., St. Louis, and even the French municipalities of Normandy and Deauville.

‚ÄúEach ride carries its own weight,‚Äù Bethards said. ‚ÄúAs excited as we are to share our mission ‚Äì it‚Äôs a heavy ride ‚Ä¶ but for all those vets that are suffering, that are all by themselves and all the pain they‚Äôre going through, it‚Äôs worth that little bit.‚Äù¬†

This year‚Äôs riders in the Big Apple represent the U.S. Army, Marine Corps, Navy and Air Force, hailing from Texas, Indiana and Illinois, as well as one Gold Star father whose child passed away during their military service.

The 14 riders have all have participated in BraveHearts‚Äô equine therapy programs and have received training prior to the ride, Hill-McQueeney said.

NYPD‚Äôs mounted police unit and similiar units from surrounding states will also be in attendance to escort riders through busy intersections over the course of the ride.

Veterans like Spandet, who is preparing for his first ride in the Big Apple, say they are ready for the challenge.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm lucky that I‚Äôve ridden Beau every week for the last three years: I have this level of trust that he‚Äôs going to see me through,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúHe has to trust that I‚Äôm going to be okay [riding] with the trains, the buses and the cabbies.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a partnership,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúand taking care of the horses helps me take care of myself.‚Äù
item.author: Nicole Rosenthal

item.description:
Her tell-all has the mayoral seal of approval.

Mayor Eric Adams surprisingly recommended his ex-girlfriend Jasmine Ray‚Äôs new memoir juicily detailing their decade-old secret relationship.

Hizzoner praised Ray ‚Äî whom he had appointed as the city‚Äôs first sports czar, a $160,000-a-year gig ‚Äî for her self-published ‚ÄúPolitical Humanity,‚Äù which provides readers a peek into the corridors of City Hall.

‚ÄúJas has always led with integrity,‚Äù he wrote in a post on X Thursday. ‚ÄúWriting this book wasn‚Äôt easy, but she wanted people to understand the work, the mission, and the human side behind the headlines.

‚ÄúI respect her for that and I enjoyed reading it. I hope all will read the book.‚Äù

Ray, 42, unflinchingly addresses her unrequited love for Adams, 65, in the memoir ‚Äî even after their two-year relationship ended in 2016.

She also exposed secrets about his elusive private life.

The book revealed Adams‚Äô heartbreak after former Mayor Michael Bloomberg endorsed Andrew Cuomo in this year‚Äôs mayoral election, as well as shockingly intimate moments Ray shared with the then-Brooklyn borough president ‚Äî such as how she‚Äôd rub a scar on the back of his head ‚Äúfor hours‚Äù to calm him down.

The former sports czar also lambasted what she considered a double standard for how prominent black politicians such as Adams are treated, even as she acknowledged that the mayor surrounded himself with cronies who weren‚Äôt fit to serve in City Hall.

The book came out shortly after Adams announced he‚Äôd drop out of New York City‚Äôs mayoral race.

Adams shouldn‚Äôt have given up his re-election bid, which was imperiled by his historic corruption case, Ray told The Post in an interview last week.

‚ÄúI think he made a mistake by quitting,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI think the city made a mistake by turning their back on him.‚Äù

The mayor hadn‚Äôt publicly disclosed his past romance with Ray before her book was announced.

He has been in a year-long relationship with his¬†girlfriend Tracey Collins ‚Äî a matter that wasn‚Äôt discussed in Ray‚Äôs book.
item.author: Matt Troutman
